help.text:
The software does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate.
When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The software might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the software might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.
help.markdown:
The software does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate.
When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The software might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the software might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

fullDescription.text: The software does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate.

shortDescription.text: Improper Certificate Validation.

help.text:
The software uses external input to construct a pathname that is intended to identify a file or directory that is located underneath a restricted parent directory, but the software does not properly neutralize special elements within the pathname that can cause the pathname to resolve to a location that is outside of the restricted directory.
Many file operations are intended to take place within a restricted directory. By using special elements such as .. and / separators, attackers can escape outside of the restricted location to access files or directories that are elsewhere on the system. One of the most common special elements is the ../ sequence, which in most modern operating systems is interpreted as the parent directory of the current location. This is referred to as relative path traversal. Path traversal also covers the use of absolute pathnames such as /usr/local/bin, which may also be useful in accessing unexpected files. This is referred to as absolute path traversal. In many programming languages, the injection of a null byte (the 0 or NUL) may allow an attacker to truncate a generated filename to widen the scope of attack. For example, the software may add .txt to any pathname, thus limiting the attacker to text files, but a null injection may effectively remove this restriction.
help.markdown:
The software uses external input to construct a pathname that is intended to identify a file or directory that is located underneath a restricted parent directory, but the software does not properly neutralize special elements within the pathname that can cause the pathname to resolve to a location that is outside of the restricted directory.
Many file operations are intended to take place within a restricted directory. By using special elements such as .. and / separators, attackers can escape outside of the restricted location to access files or directories that are elsewhere on the system. One of the most common special elements is the ../ sequence, which in most modern operating systems is interpreted as the parent directory of the current location. This is referred to as relative path traversal. Path traversal also covers the use of absolute pathnames such as /usr/local/bin, which may also be useful in accessing unexpected files. This is referred to as absolute path traversal. In many programming languages, the injection of a null byte (the 0 or NUL) may allow an attacker to truncate a generated filename to widen the scope of attack. For example, the software may add .txt to any pathname, thus limiting the attacker to text files, but a null injection may effectively remove this restriction.

fullDescription.text: The software uses external input to construct a pathname that is intended to identify a file or directory that is located underneath a restricted parent directory, but the software does not properly neutralize special elements within the pathname that can cause the pathname to resolve to a location that is outside of the restricted directory.

shortDescription.text: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal').

help.text:
The software constructs a string for a command to executed by a separate component in another control sphere, but it does not properly delimit the intended arguments, options, or switches within that command string.
When creating commands using interpolation into a string, developers may assume that only the arguments/options that they specify will be processed. This assumption may be even stronger when the programmer has encoded the command in a way that prevents separate commands from being provided maliciously, e.g. in the case of shell metacharacters. When constructing the command, the developer may use whitespace or other delimiters that are required to separate arguments when the command. However, if an attacker can provide an untrusted input that contains argument-separating delimiters, then the resulting command will have more arguments than intended by the developer. The attacker may then be able to change the behavior of the command. Depending on the functionality supported by the extraneous arguments, this may have security-relevant consequences.
help.markdown:
The software constructs a string for a command to executed by a separate component in another control sphere, but it does not properly delimit the intended arguments, options, or switches within that command string.
When creating commands using interpolation into a string, developers may assume that only the arguments/options that they specify will be processed. This assumption may be even stronger when the programmer has encoded the command in a way that prevents separate commands from being provided maliciously, e.g. in the case of shell metacharacters. When constructing the command, the developer may use whitespace or other delimiters that are required to separate arguments when the command. However, if an attacker can provide an untrusted input that contains argument-separating delimiters, then the resulting command will have more arguments than intended by the developer. The attacker may then be able to change the behavior of the command. Depending on the functionality supported by the extraneous arguments, this may have security-relevant consequences.

fullDescription.text: The software constructs a string for a command to executed by a separate component in another control sphere, but it does not properly delimit the intended arguments, options, or switches within that command string.

shortDescription.text: Improper Neutralization of Argument Delimiters in a Command ('Argument Injection').

help.text:
The software does not handle or incorrectly handles a compressed input with a very high compression ratio that produces a large output.
An example of data amplification is a decompression bomb, a small ZIP file that can produce a large amount of data when it is decompressed.
help.markdown:
The software does not handle or incorrectly handles a compressed input with a very high compression ratio that produces a large output.
An example of data amplification is a decompression bomb, a small ZIP file that can produce a large amount of data when it is decompressed.

fullDescription.text: The software does not handle or incorrectly handles a compressed input with a very high compression ratio that produces a large output.

shortDescription.text: Improper Handling of Highly Compressed Data (Data Amplification).

help.text: The product, upon installation, sets incorrect permissions for an object that exposes it to an unintended actor.
help.markdown: The product, upon installation, sets incorrect permissions for an object that exposes it to an unintended actor.

fullDescription.text: The product, upon installation, sets incorrect permissions for an object that exposes it to an unintended actor.

shortDescription.text: Incorrect Default Permissions.

help.text: The software does not properly anticipate or handle exceptional conditions that rarely occur during normal operation of the software.
help.markdown: The software does not properly anticipate or handle exceptional conditions that rarely occur during normal operation of the software.

fullDescription.text: The software does not properly anticipate or handle exceptional conditions that rarely occur during normal operation of the software.

shortDescription.text: Improper Check or Handling of Exceptional Conditions.
